description:
Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. conglutinans is a fungal plant pathogen that causes a disease known as Fusarium wilt in cruciferous crops, particularly cabbage and cauliflower. It is a forma specialis (f. sp.) of the Fusarium oxysporum species, which means it is a specialized form that primarily infects and causes disease in plants of the Brassicaceae family.

The fungus can survive in the soil as dormant structures called chlamydospores, which can remain viable for several years. When the host plant is present, the chlamydospores germinate and the fungus invades the plant's vascular system, disrupting water and nutrient transport. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of Fusarium wilt, such as wilting, stunting, and discoloration of the leaves and stems.

Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. conglutinans is considered a significant threat to commercial cabbage and cauliflower production, as it can cause substantial yield losses and is difficult to control due to its ability to persist in the soil. Management strategies often involve the use of resistant cultivars, crop rotation, and soil fumigation, among other integrated pest management approaches.
